message_1:
Let X be a set of real numbers and let A be the set of all open intervals of the form (a,b) such that 0 < a < b. Define a collection K = {C ⊂ A : C is finite or C is the complement of a finite set}, and let Y = ∪ C∈K C. Show that Y is compact. 

For instance, prove that the open cover {Uα} of Y has a finite subcover.
message_2:
To show that Y is compact, we need to prove that every open cover of Y has a finite subcover. Let {Uα} be an arbitrary open cover of Y. Since Y = ∪ C∈K C, we have that for each C ∈ K, there exists an α(C) such that C ⊆ Uα(C). We will consider two cases:

Case 1: C is finite.
Since C is finite, there are only finitely many elements in C, say {c1, c2, ..., cn}. For each ci, there exists an α(ci) such that ci ∈ Uα(ci). Thus, the finite subcover {Uα(c1), Uα(c2), ..., Uα(cn)} covers C.

Case 2: C is the complement of a finite set.
Let F be the finite set such that C = A \ F. Since F is finite, there are only finitely many elements in F, say {f1, f2, ..., fn}. For each fi, there exists an α(fi) such that fi ∈ Uα(fi). Now, consider the set A \ {Uα(f1), Uα(f2), ..., Uα(fn)}. This set is a subset of C, so there exists an α(C) such that A \ {Uα(f1), Uα(f2), ..., Uα(fn)} ⊆ Uα(C). Thus, the finite subcover {Uα(f1), Uα(f2), ..., Uα(fn), Uα(C)} covers C.

In both cases, we have found a finite subcover of {Uα} that covers C. Since this holds for every C ∈ K, we can take the union of these finite subcovers to obtain a finite subcover of {Uα} that covers Y. Therefore, Y is compact.
